items.title: Big City, Crazy Killer, Loner Cop
items.abstract: In Warren Ellis’s “Gun Machine” a murderous psychopath who believes he is a resident of pre-colonial Manhattan is tracked by a messy, isolated police detective.

items.title: Record Number of Misconduct Complaints Are Made Against City School Employees
items.abstract: The office of the Special Commissioner of Investigation handled 4,173 complaints, more than double the amount received during the first year of the Bloomberg administration.

items.title: New York City Ties Doctors’ Income to Quality of Care
items.abstract: A proposal affecting physicians in public hospitals represents a push away from the traditional model of rewarding doctors for the volume of the services they order.
keywords: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

items.title: Swiss City Fears for Cultural Legacy in Wake of a Bank’s Fall
items.abstract: Wegelin, a significant sponsor of cultural institutions, was charged in the United States with illegally helping American citizens avoid taxes and split up its valuable assets.

items.title: Maker Hid Data About Design Flaw in Hip Implant, Records Show
items.abstract: Johnson & Johnson executives were aware that an artificial hip had a critical design flaw years before it was recalled, but concealed that information, according to documents disclosed at a trial.

items.title: In Rural Alabama, a Longtime Mistrust of Medicine Fuels a Tuberculosis Outbreak
items.abstract: Marion, Ala., is in the throes of a tuberculosis outbreak so severe that it has posted an incidence rate that is about 100 times greater than the state’s and worse than many developing countries.

items.title: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
items.abstract: A new bill could make many “quality of life” violations civil, not criminal, offenses, helping to ease the overpolicing in communities of color.

items.title: Sam Shepard Takes Stock of ‘Buried Child’ and the Writer’s Life
items.abstract: Mr. Shepard comments on his play, soon to have its third major production in New York; his upbringing; and the limitations he finds in his own oeuvre.

items.title: ‘Dream Cities,’ by Wade Graham
items.abstract: The ideas and structures that created today’s cities, and the architects and planners who implemented them.
keywords: Dream Cities: Seven Urban Ideas That Shape the World (Book)

items.title: New York Police Still Struggle to Follow Street-Stop Rules, Report Finds
items.abstract: The findings, in a report filed by the federal monitor, Peter L. Zimroth, portray an agency straining to make its routine inquiries of citizens constitutional.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: How New York City Ended Up With 2 Competing Women’s Marches
items.abstract: At issue is the question of inclusivity, one that has haunted the national movement since its inception.

items.title: A Rogue Mascot Causes Headaches for a Japanese City
items.abstract: Chiitan, an unauthorized mascot for the city of Susaki, raised eyebrows with its non-child-friendly stunts, like swinging a weed whacker and tipping over a car.

items.title: Wall Street’s Slide Hurts New York; City Loses Nearly $1 Billion in Tax Revenue
items.abstract: Thursday’s report of a sharp decline in income tax revenue for New York City is a nearly $1 billion surprise: Is it an anomaly, or the new normal?

items.title: Review: A Tenor Reaches 18 High C’s at the Metropolitan Opera
items.abstract: Javier Camarena responded to an ecstatic ovation after his big aria in Donizetti’s “La Fille du Régiment” by repeating the piece and its high notes.

items.title: Party for Hong Kong’s Elite Angers a City Under Covid Controls
items.abstract: Just as new restrictions were being imposed, top politicians were found to have attended a large gathering where at least one person had Covid.

items.title: ‘American Urbanist,’ a Well-Timed Biography of a Man Who Reshaped City Life
items.abstract: Richard K. Rein’s book tells the story of William H. Whyte, a sociologist who wrote “The Organization Man” and helped to rethink how cities look and feel.
keywords: American Urbanist: How William H Whyte's Unconventional Wisdom Reshaped Public Life (Book)

items.title: New Virus Cases Begin to Slow in U.S. Cities Where Omicron Hit First
items.abstract: Reports of infections are falling in Cleveland, Newark and Washington, suggesting that a national peak may be approaching.

items.title: A New York City anime convention was not a superspreader event, a C.D.C. study finds.
items.abstract: The rate of positive results among attendees who took coronavirus tests was about the same as that of New York City at large, researchers found.
keywords: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Javits, Jacob K, Convention Center (Manhattan, NY)

items.title: New York City Plans to Stop Homeless People From Sheltering in Subway
items.abstract: The plan calls for stricter enforcement of transit system rules and more mental-health services and housing options for those being cleared from stations and trains.
